policies.name: System and Services Acquisition Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing the acquisition, development, and modification of systems and system components with security requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.16.01 requires applying security engineering principles to development and modification, which necessitates formal policy guidance for system acquisition and development activities

policies.name: Secure Development Lifecycle Policy
policies.description: Policy establishing requirements for integrating security into all phases of system development and modification
policies.rationale: Control discussion explicitly mentions 'incorporating security requirements into the system development life cycle' as a key security engineering principle

procedures.name: Security Architecture Review Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for conducting security architecture reviews during system design, including evaluation of layered protections, security boundaries, and control placement
procedures.rationale: Control discussion requires 'establishing security policies, architectures, and controls as the foundation for system design' and 'delineating physical and logical security boundaries'

procedures.name: Threat Modeling Procedure
procedures.description: Process for performing threat modeling exercises identifying use cases, threat agents, attack vectors, attack patterns, design patterns, and compensating controls
procedures.rationale: Control discussion explicitly requires 'performing threat modeling to identify use cases, threat agents, attack vectors and patterns, design patterns, and compensating controls needed to mitigate risk'

procedures.name: Secure Development Training Procedure
procedures.description: Process for ensuring developers receive training on building trustworthy, secure software and implementing security engineering principles
procedures.rationale: Control discussion explicitly requires 'ensuring that developers are trained on how to build trustworthy secure software'

executionEvidence.name: Security Architecture Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports for each system development or major modification project showing: security principles applied, layered protection design, security boundaries defined, control placement decisions, architecture review findings, approver signatures
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Must be completed before implementation phase begins
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires applying security engineering principles during development/modification; architecture reviews demonstrate principle application at the design phase

executionEvidence.name: Threat Modeling Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Threat model reports for each system showing: system use cases, identified threat agents, attack vectors and patterns, security design patterns employed, compensating controls implemented, risk mitigations, modeling date and participants
executionEvidence.frequency: Per project (new systems and major modifications)
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Must be completed before implementation begins; updated when system changes significantly
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion explicitly requires 'performing threat modeling to identify use cases, threat agents, attack vectors and patterns, design patterns, and compensating controls'

executionEvidence.name: Secure Development Training Certificates
executionEvidence.description: Training completion records showing: developer name, training date, secure coding topics covered (OWASP Top 10, secure SDLC, threat modeling), assessment scores, certificate issuance
executionEvidence.frequency: Annual for all developers and architects
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 18 months - developers should receive refresher training at least annually
executionEvidence.rationale: Control discussion requires 'ensuring that developers are trained on how to build trustworthy secure software'; annual training aligns with NIST and industry standards

executionEvidence.name: SDLC Security Gate Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Phase gate review documentation showing: security requirements defined at project initiation, security design reviewed at design phase, secure coding practices applied during development, security testing completed before deployment, security sign-off obtained
executionEvidence.frequency: Per project (at each SDLC phase gate)
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Must be current to project phase - no phase should proceed without previous phase security sign-off
executionEvidence.rationale: Control discussion requires 'incorporating security requirements into the system development life cycle'; gate documentation demonstrates integration throughout SDLC

executionEvidence.name: Security Requirements Traceability Matrix
executionEvidence.description: Matrix for each project showing: security requirements identified, design elements implementing each requirement, test cases validating each requirement, verification of implementation, traceability to security engineering principles
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Must be updated at each SDLC phase and remain current throughout project
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates systematic application of security engineering principles by tracing requirements through design, implementation, and testing phases

operationalActivities: Conduct security architecture reviews during system design phase
Perform threat modeling for new systems and major modifications
Provide annual secure development training to all developers and architects
Integrate security requirements into SDLC phase gates
Document security engineering principles applied to each project
Develop layered protection designs with defined security boundaries
Review and approve security designs before implementation
Maintain security requirements traceability throughout projects
Apply secure coding practices during development
Assess and manage security risks throughout system lifecycle

policies.name: System and Services Acquisition Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing system component lifecycle management including acquisition, maintenance, and replacement
policies.rationale: NIST 03.16.02 requires replacing unsupported components and managing risks when replacement is not feasible, which necessitates formal policy on component lifecycle management

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Policy establishing requirements for tracking system components, managing changes, and maintaining component inventories including support status
policies.rationale: Control requires identifying components when support is no longer available, which depends on effective configuration management and component tracking

procedures.name: Unsupported Component Identification Procedure
procedures.description: Process for tracking vendor support lifecycles, identifying components approaching end-of-support, and escalating unsupported components for action
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires replacing components 'when support is no longer available from the developer, vendor, or manufacturer' - identification is the critical first step

procedures.name: Component Replacement Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for planning, approving, and executing replacement of unsupported components including testing, migration, and cutover activities
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (a) explicitly requires 'Replace system components when support for the components is no longer available'

procedures.name: Unsupported Component Risk Mitigation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for assessing risks of unsupported components that cannot be replaced and implementing compensating controls such as network isolation, enhanced monitoring, or restricted access
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (b) requires 'Provide options for risk mitigation or alternative sources for continued support for unsupported components that cannot be replaced'

executionEvidence.name: Software and Hardware Inventory with Support Status
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive inventory showing: component name and version, vendor/manufacturer, current support status (supported/approaching EOL/unsupported), end-of-support date, last update received, support contract information, criticality rating
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 120 days - quarterly reviews should be completed within 30 days of quarter end
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires identifying when support is no longer available; this evidence tracks support status across all components to enable timely replacement planning

executionEvidence.name: Vendor End-of-Life Notifications
executionEvidence.description: Collected vendor notifications showing: product name, end-of-support date, end-of-life date, recommended replacement or upgrade path, date notification received, acknowledgment by responsible personnel
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - maintained as historical record for audit trail
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates organization is receiving and tracking vendor notifications about support status changes, enabling proactive replacement planning

executionEvidence.name: Unsupported Component Replacement Plans
executionEvidence.description: Plans for each unsupported component showing: component details, reason support ended, replacement component identified, replacement timeline, testing requirements, cutover plan, resource assignments, approvals
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Should be created within 30 days of identifying unsupported component; execution should begin immediately based on risk
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires replacing unsupported components; replacement plans demonstrate systematic approach to meeting this requirement

executionEvidence.name: Risk Assessments for Unsupported Components
executionEvidence.description: Risk assessment documents for components that cannot be replaced showing: component details, reason replacement is not feasible, vulnerabilities and threats identified, likelihood and impact ratings, overall risk score, risk acceptance authority signature
executionEvidence.frequency: Per unsupported component that cannot be replaced
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 90 days - risk assessments should be reviewed quarterly while component remains unsupported
executionEvidence.rationale: Control discussion notes exceptions to replacement include systems providing critical capabilities when newer technologies unavailable or systems are isolated; risk assessment justifies exceptions

executionEvidence.name: Risk Mitigation Documentation for Unsupported Components
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: compensating controls implemented (network isolation, enhanced logging, restricted access), alternative support arrangements (in-house support, third-party maintenance), monitoring requirements, periodic reassessment schedule, management approval
executionEvidence.frequency: Per unsupported component that cannot be replaced
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 120 days - mitigation effectiveness should be reviewed quarterly
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (b) explicitly requires 'Provide options for risk mitigation or alternative sources for continued support'; this evidence documents the mitigations implemented

executionEvidence.name: Alternative Support Contracts and Agreements
executionEvidence.description: Contracts or agreements with third-party vendors or documentation of in-house support capabilities showing: components covered, support services provided, patch development process, incident response commitments, contract term, cost
executionEvidence.frequency: Per unsupported component requiring alternative support
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Contracts should remain active for duration component is in use; reviewed annually
executionEvidence.rationale: Control discussion explicitly mentions 'obtain the services of external service providers who provide ongoing support' and 'establish in-house support by developing customized patches'

operationalActivities: Track vendor support lifecycles for all system components
Monitor vendor notifications for end-of-life announcements
Identify components approaching or at end-of-support
Assess feasibility of replacing unsupported components
Develop and execute replacement plans for unsupported components
Conduct risk assessments for components that cannot be replaced
Implement compensating controls for unsupported components (isolation, enhanced monitoring)
Establish alternative support arrangements (third-party vendors, in-house capabilities)
Review effectiveness of risk mitigations quarterly
Update component inventory with support status changes
Escalate high-risk unsupported components to management

policies.name: System and Services Acquisition Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing the acquisition and use of external system services including security requirements, risk management, and oversight responsibilities
policies.rationale: NIST 03.16.03 requires defining security requirements for external service providers handling CUI, which necessitates formal policy on external service acquisition and management

policies.name: Vendor Management Policy
policies.description: Policy establishing requirements for vendor selection, assessment, monitoring, and management including security requirements for vendors processing CUI
policies.rationale: Control requires requiring external service providers to comply with security requirements and monitoring their compliance; vendor management policy provides the governance framework

policies.name: Third-Party Risk Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining the organization's approach to assessing and managing risks from external service providers, including those processing, storing, or transmitting CUI
policies.rationale: Control discussion states 'The responsibility for managing risks from the use of external system services remains with the organization charged with protecting CUI'

procedures.name: External Service Provider Security Assessment Procedure
procedures.description: Process for assessing external service providers before engagement including security requirement verification, control validation, risk assessment, and approval workflow
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires providers 'to comply with the following security requirements' - assessment procedure ensures requirements are evaluated before engagement

procedures.name: External Service Provider Monitoring Procedure
procedures.description: Process for ongoing monitoring of external provider security compliance including periodic reviews, audit report collection, incident tracking, and compliance verification
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (c) explicitly requires 'Implement processes, methods, and techniques to monitor security requirement compliance by external service providers on an ongoing basis'

procedures.name: Service Level Agreement Development Procedure
procedures.description: Process for developing and negotiating SLAs with external providers including security requirements, measurable outcomes, remedies, and response requirements for noncompliance
procedures.rationale: Control discussion states 'Service-level agreements define expectations of performance, describe measurable outcomes, and identify remedies, mitigations, and response requirements for instances of noncompliance'

procedures.name: Shared Responsibility Documentation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for defining and documenting roles, responsibilities, and shared security obligations between the organization and external service providers
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (b) explicitly requires 'Define and document user roles and responsibilities with regard to external system services, including shared responsibilities with external service providers'

executionEvidence.name: External Service Provider Inventory
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive inventory showing: provider name, services provided, CUI processing/storage/transmission status, contract dates, security requirements applicable, last assessment date, compliance status, risk rating
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 45 days - inventory should be reviewed and updated monthly to remain current
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires monitoring compliance of external providers; inventory is foundational for tracking which providers require oversight and their compliance status

executionEvidence.name: Service Contracts with Security Requirements
executionEvidence.description: Executed contracts or agreements showing: security requirements specified in contract language, CUI handling provisions, incident notification requirements, audit rights, termination clauses for security violations, security addenda, executed signatures
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: Contracts must be current/active; reviewed annually for adequacy
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires providers to 'comply with the following security requirements' - contracts formalize these requirements and provider obligations

executionEvidence.name: Service Level Agreements with Security Clauses
executionEvidence.description: SLAs showing: security performance metrics, availability requirements, incident response times, security incident notification requirements, remediation timeframes, penalties for noncompliance, measurement methods
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: SLAs must be active; reviewed quarterly for performance
executionEvidence.rationale: Control discussion requires SLAs to 'define expectations of performance, describe measurable outcomes, and identify remedies, mitigations, and response requirements for instances of noncompliance'

executionEvidence.name: Shared Responsibility Matrices (RACI)
executionEvidence.description: Documented shared responsibility matrices showing: security functions (access control, encryption, logging, patching, etc.), organization responsibilities, provider responsibilities, accountability assignments, consultation requirements, information flows
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 120 days - should be reviewed quarterly and updated when services or responsibilities change
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (b) explicitly requires 'Define and document user roles and responsibilities with regard to external system services, including shared responsibilities with external service providers'

executionEvidence.name: External Provider Security Assessment Reports
executionEvidence.description: Pre-engagement and periodic assessment reports showing: security requirements evaluated, controls verified, gaps identified, risk assessment results, remediation required, approval decision, assessor name and date
executionEvidence.frequency: Initial assessment before engagement, then annually
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 18 months - annual assessments should be completed; initial assessment required before any CUI processing
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires providers to comply with security requirements; assessments verify compliance before and during engagement

executionEvidence.name: External Provider Compliance Monitoring Reports
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly monitoring reports showing: providers reviewed, security requirements verified, compliance status, incidents or issues identified, remediation actions required, follow-up dates, reviewer signatures
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 120 days - quarterly monitoring should be completed within 30 days of quarter end
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (c) requires 'monitor security requirement compliance by external service providers on an ongoing basis' - quarterly monitoring demonstrates ongoing oversight

executionEvidence.name: Third-Party Audit Reports and Certifications
executionEvidence.description: External audit reports collected from providers showing: SOC 2 Type II reports, ISO 27001 certificates, FedRAMP authorization, other relevant certifications, report dates, scope, findings, remediation status
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: 18 months - audit reports should be current (less than 12 months old); certifications should be valid
executionEvidence.rationale: Third-party audit reports are a key method for verifying external provider compliance with security requirements as required by control requirement (c)

executionEvidence.name: Provider Non-Compliance Incident Log
executionEvidence.description: Log of security compliance issues showing: provider name, date identified, nature of non-compliance, security impact, required remediation, provider response, resolution date, verification of fix, escalation if needed
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - maintained as historical record; open items should be tracked for timely resolution
executionEvidence.rationale: Control discussion requires 'remedies, mitigations, and response requirements for instances of noncompliance' - incident log tracks noncompliance and remediation

operationalActivities: Maintain inventory of all external services processing, storing, or transmitting CUI
Define security requirements for external service providers
Assess external providers before engagement for security compliance
Document shared responsibilities with external providers (RACI matrices)
Incorporate security requirements into contracts and SLAs
Collect and review third-party audit reports (SOC 2, ISO 27001, FedRAMP)
Monitor external provider security compliance quarterly
Track and remediate provider non-compliance issues
Review provider security posture annually
Update contracts and SLAs with security requirements
Conduct security incident coordination with external providers
Escalate high-risk provider issues to management
Terminate provider relationships for significant security violations
